white reference bar: A flat, uniformly reflective element incorporated into the edge of an imaging spectroscopy dataset, used to correct for variations in illumination and sensor response, allowing for accurate representation of spectral signatures and facilitating identification of subtle changes in reflectance patterns.

A reference component used in imaging spectroscopy to account for variations in illumination conditions, ensuring that subsequent image processing maintains accurate spectral information by providing a standardized reflectance signature against which measured data can be calibrated.

A calibration tool used in high-resolution imaging spectroscopy to compensate for varying illumination conditions and ensure accurate measurement of spectral data by providing a standardized reflection value, thereby allowing for precise characterization of sample properties and monitoring of temporal changes.

A calibration aid consisting of a reflective surface, usually located at the edge of an image, that helps to normalize illumination conditions and counteract wavelength-dependent sensor responses, thus ensuring accurate spectral data collection in the visible and near-infrared spectrum.

A calibration element placed within the field of view of a hyperspectral imaging system to compensate for variations in illumination conditions, thereby enabling accurate measurement of spectral data.
herbicide monitoring: The systematic observation and recording of subtle changes in the spectral reflectance patterns of plants, allowing for the detection of targeted substances' effects and their timing, thereby enabling informed management and mitigation strategies.

The process of quantitatively tracking and analyzing the biochemical and physiological responses of living organisms to targeted, chemical substances, facilitating early detection and assessment of their efficacy and potentially harmful effects.

The process of using high-resolution, high-frequency measurements of reflective spectral signatures to track and quantify changes in the chemical composition or physiological responses of plants to environmental influences, such as targeted agents, over short-term intervals.
The systematic observation and recording of the temporal changes in the spectral characteristics of plant species in response to external chemical agents applied for the purpose of selective control.

The process of tracking the temporal changes in the reflectance characteristics of targeted plant populations in response to specific environmental factors or treatments, using high-resolution imaging spectroscopy, in order to assess the effectiveness and impact of these factors on plant health and behavior.

High-resolution images of specific properties across a wide range of wavelengths, capturing subtle changes in the reflective behavior of objects, such as vegetation, over time, allowing for the detection of subtle differences and patterns that may indicate underlying biological or chemical alterations.

A multidimensional dataset comprising high-spectral-resolution images captured across a wide range of wavelengths, capturing subtle changes in reflected radiation that reveal intricate details about the chemical and physical properties of objects or surfaces, such as the effects of herbicides on the reflectance characteristics of plants.

The process of analyzing reflected or emitted light from a subject to gather information about its chemical and physical properties, capturing a range of light frequencies that are perceptible to the human eye and just beyond, to reveal detailed insights into its composition, behavior, and response to environmental stimuli.

A phenomenon caused by changes in the angle of incidence of light as an object moves within the field of view of a sensor, resulting in subtle variations in the recorded signal that can lead to distortions and oscillations in the data.
